Take-home Exercise 2

Peer critique and viz makeover of age-sex pyramid design.

Author

Michael Djohan

Published

January 24, 2023

1. Overview

This exercise aims to provide critique and improvements to age-sex (population) pyramid created by peer in Take Home Exercise 1 using Tableau. This will be done based on clarity and aesthetics. The original design will then be remade using data visualization design principles and best practices using ggplot2, its extensions, and tidyverse packages.

The original dataset was downloaded from Department of Statistics, Singapore, titled Singapore Residents by Planning Area / Subzone, Age Group, Sex and Type of Dwelling, June 2022.

The file downloaded was respopagesextod2022.csv.

2. Data Visualization Critique

2.1 Original Design

Figure 1 below shows the original design of the Singapore population pyramid by Planning Area in June 2022.

The embedded dashboard Tableau dashboard is presented below as well. It can also be referred here

2.2 Critique : Clarity and Aesthetics

Clarity

  • While Tableau displays dynamic chart, the lack of x-axis here makes it difficult to gauge the data (male and female population). This also potentially mislead audience as it wrongly presents different planning areas have similar population size (i.e., population size of Downtown Core is much smaller than Tampines, but the length of the bars show that they are similar). This is because the scales of x-axis for different pyramids are inconsistent.

  • Lack of legends, making it difficult to determine which side represents Male or Female population.

  • The title is descriptive, but not specific. For instance, it does not tell the audience which period was this from. Additionally, it does not tell the audience the context of the visualization (i.e., main highlight, story, etc). A well-worded title and subtitle should help here.

  • Lack of references for audience to compare across different facets, having relevant data labels or reference line would improve readability.

  • Audience has to scroll down on each individual pyramid, making it difficult to observe patterns from quick glance.

  • The order of the planning areas in the trellis chart is not meaningful.

  • The presence of grid lines without x-axis is meaningless.

  • Lack of caption to present the source of data.

Aesthetics

  • Good color choices representing Male and Female population, making it easy to read.

  • Clear planning area labels for each population pyramid.

  • Uniform white background gives a clean look.

  • Soft grid lines are not distracting.

  • Y-axis labels are not very easy to read due to presence of “_”.

3. Makeover Design

3.1 Proposed Sketch

Rough sketch of proposed design is shown below

From the original visualization, it seems that the original author intends to contrast different population sizes and patterns across Singapore planning areas. This might be the reason for choosing low populated area like “Downtown Core” and highly populated area like “Tampines”. As such, it is proposed to plot the absolute (based on total population) of the age-sex pyramids of the original planning areas, ordered based on population sizes. Rough sketch of proposed design is shown below.

Another angle of visualizing age-sex pyramids is by plotting the proportion pyramids (based on proportion% of total population). This will highlight the population patterns better without being influenced by the population size. With this, we could also add reference step chart based on Singapore overall population proportion %. It is also important to have data labels highlighting the population of each planning area to avoid misleading the audience.

3.2 Data Preparation

Launch R packages and import data from csv

Show the code 
#Load packages
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, cowplot, scales)

#Import data
sgpop <- read_csv("data/respopagesextod2022.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

The loaded data needs to be modified before plotting. The list of modifications are as follows:

  • Group the original data by planning area, age, and sex

  • Convert Males population to negative to reverse the bar chart axis

  • Derive new variables to calculate population proportion - sum of population by PA, sum of total population, and the relevant proportions

  • Derive “signal” variable to help to position data labels in min/max values on the respective Males and Females charts

  • Factorize “Sex” and “AG” to order its level in the plots

Show the code 
#Data Cleaning
#sgpop_group groups total population by PA, AG, and Sex to create base data for population pyramid
sgpop_group <- sgpop |> 
  mutate(AG = gsub('_',' ', AG),
         Pop = ifelse(Sex == "Males", Pop*(-1), Pop)) |>
  group_by(PA, AG, Sex) |> 
  summarise(sum_pop = sum(Pop)) 

#sgpop_max_min creates summary parameters for max, min, and sum by grouping them on PA and Sex. AG is not included since we want to find total population across age group
sgpop_max_min <- sgpop_group |> 
  group_by(PA, Sex) |> 
  summarise(max_pop = max(abs(sum_pop)),
            min_pop = min(abs(sum_pop)))

#sgpop_sum sums up the total population by planning area. This will be used to create proportion population per planning area
sgpop_sum <- sgpop_group |> 
  group_by (PA) |> 
  summarise(sum_pop_pa = sum(abs(sum_pop)))

#sgpop_total groups total population by AG and Sex to create base data for total Singapore population (across different PA)
sgpop_total <- sgpop |>
  mutate(AG = gsub('_',' ', AG),
         Pop = ifelse(Sex == "Males", Pop*(-1), Pop)) |>
  group_by(AG, Sex) |> 
  summarise(sum_pop_total = sum(Pop)) 

#sgpop_total_summ sums total Singapore population. This will be used to create Singapore proportion population for reference
sgpop_total_summ <- sgpop_total |> 
  group_by (Sex) |> 
  summarise(sum_pop_total_ag = sum(sum_pop_total)) |> 
  mutate(sum_pop_total_sg = sum(abs(sum_pop_total_ag)))

#joining multiple tibbles to create final sgpop_clean
sgpop_draft1 = sgpop_group |> left_join(sgpop_max_min, by = c('PA'='PA', 'Sex' = 'Sex')) 
sgpop_draft2 = sgpop_draft1 |> left_join(sgpop_sum, by = c('PA' = 'PA'))
sgpop_draft3 = sgpop_draft2 |> left_join(sgpop_total, by = c('AG' = 'AG', 'Sex' = 'Sex'))
sgpop_clean = sgpop_draft3 |> left_join(sgpop_total_summ, by = 'Sex')

#adding new variables:
#signal is used to display labels for min and max values in population pyramid
#prop_pop is proportion population per planning area
#prop_pop_total is proportion population of Singapore
sgpop_clean <- sgpop_clean |> 
  mutate(signal = case_when((min_pop == abs(sum_pop) | max_pop == abs(sum_pop)) & Sex == "Males" ~ -1,
                            (min_pop == abs(sum_pop) | max_pop == abs(sum_pop)) & Sex == "Females" ~ 1,
                            TRUE~0),
         prop_pop = round(sum_pop/sum_pop_pa*100, 1),
         prop_pop_total = abs(round(sum_pop_total/sum_pop_total_sg*100, 1))
         )

#Order factors
sgpop_clean$Sex <- fct_relevel(sgpop_clean$Sex, "Males")
sgpop_clean$AG  <- fct_relevel(sgpop_clean$AG, "0 to 4", "5 to 9")

3.2 Creating function to plot the charts

Functions are used to plot the charts to give flexibility to user(s) to input their selected 9 planning areas, ordered by their preference. In this case, however, we will use the original 9 planning areas in the original design. Two functions are created :

  1. Function plot_PA_pop is created to plot age-sex pyramids based on absolute population. This takes argument of vector of strings of the planning areas.
Show the code 
#Setting the axis range and limits
pop_range_breaks = seq(-15000,15000,7500)   
pop_range_limits = c(-16000, 16000)                   

#Create function to plot based on absolute population
plot_PA_pop <- function(planning_area) {
  sgpop_clean$PA  <- fct_relevel(sgpop_clean$PA, planning_area)
  ggplot(data = sgpop_clean |> 
           filter(PA %in% planning_area)) +
    
    #creating bar charts
    geom_bar(aes(x = AG,
                 y = sum_pop, 
                 fill = Sex),
             stat = "identity") +
    
    #adding labels on min and max values
    geom_text(
      data = sgpop_clean |> filter(PA %in% planning_area & signal != 0),
      aes(x = AG,
          y = sum_pop+signal*3500,
          label = comma(abs(sum_pop))
          )) +
    coord_flip() +
    
    #adding legends and customize colors
    scale_fill_manual(values = c("steelblue", "#f6546a"),
                      labels = c("Male", "Female"),
                      name = NULL) +
    
    #scale axis
    scale_y_continuous("Population",
                       limits = pop_range_limits,
                       breaks = pop_range_breaks,
                       labels = function(x){paste0(abs(x/1000),'K')}) +
    
    #adding title, subtitle, and caption
    labs(title = "Population size and patterns can differ drastically across Singapore planning areas",
         subtitle = paste0("Singapore age-sex pyramids (absolute population) by Planning Area, June 2022\nTotal Singapore Residents Population : ", comma(sgpop_clean$sum_pop_total_sg)),
         caption = "Singapore Residents by Planning Area / Subzone, Age Group, Sex and Type of Dwelling, June 2022 from Department of Statistics, Singapore") +
    
    #create trellis plot and PA population label
    facet_wrap(~PA) +
    geom_label(
      x = 18,
      y = 9000,
      aes(label = paste("Total Pop", comma(sum_pop_pa), sep = "\n")),
      hjust = "left") +
    
    #setting theme and aesthetics
    cowplot::theme_cowplot() +
    theme(axis.title.x = element_text(vjust = 0.5),
          axis.title.y = element_blank(),
          panel.grid.major.x = element_line(color = "grey90", linetype = "solid"),
          panel.grid.major.y = element_line(color = "grey90", linetype = "solid"),
          legend.position = 'top',
          legend.justification = 'center',
          panel.border = element_rect(color = "grey60", linetype = "solid", linewidth = 0.5),
          panel.spacing.x = unit(0,"line"),
          panel.spacing.y = unit(0,"line"))
}
  1. Function plot_PA_prop is created to plot age-sex pyramids based on population proportion (%). This also takes argument of vector of strings of the planning areas. However this chart also shows the reference step chart based on Singapore overall population proportion %.
Show the code 
#Setting the axis range and limits
pop_range_breaks_prop = seq(-10,10,5)                     
pop_range_limits_prop = c(-11, 11)                         

#Create function to plot based on population proportion 
plot_PA_prop <- function(planning_area) {
  sgpop_clean$PA  <- fct_relevel(sgpop_clean$PA, planning_area)
  ggplot(data = sgpop_clean |> filter(PA %in% planning_area),
         aes(group = 1)) +
    
    #creating bar charts
    geom_bar(aes(x = AG,
                 y = prop_pop, 
                 fill = Sex),
             stat = "identity") +
    
    #adding labels on min and max values
    geom_text(
      data = sgpop_clean |> filter(PA %in% planning_area & signal != 0),
      aes(x = AG,
          y = prop_pop+signal*2,
          label = paste0(abs(prop_pop),'%')
          )) +
    
    #adding reference step chart
    geom_step(data = sgpop_clean |> filter(PA %in% planning_area & Sex == "Males"),
      aes(x = AG,
          y = -prop_pop_total),
      linetype = "solid",
      color ="black") +
    geom_step(data = sgpop_clean |> filter(PA %in% planning_area & Sex == "Females"),
      aes(x = AG,
          y = prop_pop_total),
      linetype = "solid",
      color ="black") +
    coord_flip() +
    
    #adding legends and customize colors
    scale_fill_manual(values = c("steelblue", "#f6546a"),
                      labels = c("%Male", "%Female"),
                      name = NULL) +
    
    #scale axis
    scale_y_continuous("Population Proportion",
                       limits = pop_range_limits_prop,
                       breaks = pop_range_breaks_prop,
                       labels = function(x){paste0(abs(x),'%')}) +
    
    #adding title, subtitle, and caption
    labs(title = "Different demographic patterns are revealed when population proportion (%) is used in the pyramid",
         subtitle = paste0("Singapore age-sex pyramids (proportion population) by Planning Area, June 2022\nTotal Singapore Residents Population : ", comma(sgpop_clean$sum_pop_total_sg),"\nReference step chart represents Singapore overall population proportion (%)"),
         caption = "Singapore Residents by Planning Area / Subzone, Age Group, Sex and Type of Dwelling, June 2022 from Department of Statistics, Singapore") +
    
    #create trellis plot and PA population label
    facet_wrap(~PA) +
    geom_label(
      x = 18,
      y = 6,
      aes(label = paste("Total Pop", comma(sum_pop_pa), sep = "\n")),
      hjust = "left") +
        
    #setting theme and aesthetics
    cowplot::theme_cowplot() +
    theme(axis.title.x = element_text(vjust = 0.5),
          axis.title.y = element_blank(),
          panel.grid.major.x = element_line(color = "grey90", linetype = "solid"),
          panel.grid.major.y = element_line(color = "grey90", linetype = "solid"),
          legend.position = 'top',
          legend.justification = 'center',
          panel.border = element_rect(color = "grey60", linetype = "solid", linewidth = 0.5),
          panel.spacing.x = unit(0,"line"),
          panel.spacing.y = unit(0,"line")) 
}

3.3 Plotting the makeover charts

As mentioned above, the first plot contrasts different population sizes and patterns across Singapore planning areas. As such absolute age-sex pyramids are plotted in 3x3 trellis chart. The reasons for choosing 3x3 is to optimize the display in webpage. Having 9x1 or 1x9 will either require audience to scroll or squeeze the pyramids too closely together.

Show the code 
#Calling the function to plot absolute population pyramid by the nine planning areas selected by peer
plot_PA_pop(c("Changi", "Downtown Core", "Newton", "Bukit Timah","Clementi", "Sembawang", "Serangoon", "Hougang", "Tampines"))

The second plot presents an alternative angle to the same planning areas, highlighting the population patterns better without being influenced by the population size. Reference step chart based on Singapore overall population proportion % is added to allow audience to see how different planning areas population patterns differ from national proportion. Note that the reference chart is only possible to be added in the second plot as putting this in first plot will overshadow individual planning area pyramids. This is due to sheer size of Singapore population relative to each planning area.

Show the code 
#Calling the function to plot proportion population pyramid by the nine planning areas selected by peer
plot_PA_prop(c("Changi", "Downtown Core", "Newton", "Bukit Timah","Clementi", "Sembawang", "Serangoon", "Hougang", "Tampines"))

Clarity

  • Consistent scale of x-axis allows fair comparisons of population size and patterns across different planning areas. This is especially important since the range of population sizes for the planning areas differ greatly.

  • As ggplot2 plots a static chart, having grid lines are important for audience for referencing. In this case, both y and x-axis grid lines are kept to allow audience to refer even the further pyramid from the axis (top right).

  • The title describes the context of the visualization, which is to contrast population sizes and patterns across different planning areas. Subtitle also provides factual clarity of the plots with total population displayed as reference.

  • Only data labels for min and max age groups for each planning areas are provided. This is provided to still provide reference for audience without overwhelming them with too much labels.

  • Annotations on each facets with total population for different planning areas help highlighting the context further.

  • Reference step chart of second plot adds another dimension of comparison for audience.

  • Audience can compare and contrast all pyramids in one look.

  • The order of the planning areas in the trellis chart is by population size in ascending order

  • Caption is provided to present the source of data.

Aesthetics

  • Clear color choices representing Male and Female population, making it easy to read.

  • Clear planning area labels for each population pyramid.

  • Uniform white background gives a clean look.

  • Soft grid lines are not distracting.

  • Reference chart is solid line in step chart to mimic the shape of population pyramids.

4. Learning Points

This exercise resembles the first assignment closely, using the same data to visualize the trellis chart of age-sex pyramids. However it requires the students to use ggplot2, its extensions, and tidyverse packages instead of Tableau. It also adds another dimension of critique and makeover of peer works which helps to embed best practices in data visualization. The key takeaways are:

  • It is important to start by questioning the purpose and intent of the visualization. By understanding this, one can start experimenting and designing the apt visualization from different dimensions. One example would be the second plot produced in this exercise, looking at the age-sex pyramid from the population proportion (%) rather than absolute values.

  • There is no best visualization as there might be some trade-offs between clarity and aesthetics. Adding horizontal (y-axis) grid lines in this chart presented me with a dilemma as it reduces aesthetics (by cluttering the plots), but adds additional clarity, assisting the audience to refer to the age group. This is particularly important for static visualization like this.

  • Learning to critique other peer’s works help to identify pain points, to understand best practices, and to awaken new ideas that were not surfaced during Take-home Exercise 1.
